title-group.article-title: Adhesion of Lactobacillus iners AB-1 to Human Fibronectin
title-group.subtitle: A Key Mediator for Persistence in the Vagina?

article-meta.aff: 1Canadian Research and Development Centre for Probiotics, Lawson Health Research Institute, St Joseph’s Health Care, London, ON, Canada
2Departments of Microbiology and Immunology and Surgery, The University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada
3Department of Biochemistry, The University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Gregor Reid, Lawson Health Research Institute, 268 Grosvenor Street, Rm F2-116, London, ON, Canada, N6A 4V2 Email: gregor@uwo.ca

abstract.p: Lactobacillus iners is prominent in the human vagina and is able to persist despite development of bacterial vaginosis and treatment with antibiotics. A probable factor in its persistent survival is its ability to be retained in the vaginal epithelia. Genome sequencing of the strain showed an organism deplete of many metabolic pathways, yet equipped with fibronectin (Fn)-binding adhesins. The objective of the present study was to assess the ability of L iners AB-1 to bind immobilized Fn. Results showed that the organism superiorly bound the protein compared to other species of Lactobacillus and known binders such as Staphylococcus aureus. Treatment of L iners cells by protease rendered its binding abilities to Fn nonfunctional. The findings indicate a mechanism of vaginal persistence for a Lactobacillus species, with implications for reproductive health.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The vaginal microbiota plays an important role in maintaining female and fetal health, with over 250 bacterial species identified. 1 –3 It has been known for some time that a healthy vagina is dominated by Lactobacillus species, in particular Lactobacillus iners and Lactobacillus crispatus. A shift from this state can result in aberrant conditions such as bacterial vaginosis (BV) 1
–4 and aerobic vaginitis 5 as well as urinary tract infection. 6,7

The predominant species in the vagina as determined by 16S ribosomal RNA gene sequencing is L iners. 2,8 –10 Due to its fastidious requirements, this species has been largely overlooked in the past bacteriologically based studies. In a deep sequencing study of women with BV, L iners was the only species to increase in number following metronidazole treatment, demonstrating its unique ability to persist in the fluctuating vaginal environments. 2 Lactobacillus iners has also been shown in vitro to displace biofilms of Gardnerella vaginalis, 11 a bacterium associated with BV. 2,10 Others have suggested that because L iners can be found in women with infection, the species is not protective, 4,12 but recent studies show that L iners changes its gene expression to adapt to BV conditions by increasing metabolic activity against carbohydrates (manuscript submitted). This suggests that L iners may provide a nidus for recovery from BV and restoration of homeostasis.

Adhesion is the first step in bacterial colonization of a surface and in the gastrointestinal tract Lactobacillus adhesion is commonly mediated by mucus-binding proteins. 13 Adhesion is also believed to play a role in pathogen exclusion via blockage of their binding sites in the mucosa. 14 The ability to produce adhesion proteins has been shown in the genome of L iners AB-1, potentially providing it with a means to colonize the vagina. 15 Genomic sequencing of the strain L iners AB-1 revealed that it is the smallest Lactobacillus genome known to date (1.3 Mb), and lacks better known adhesion molecules common to other Lactobacillus species, none of which have the persistence capability of L iners. This suggests that L iners contains somewhat a unique mechanism to persist in the host.

A predicted fibronectin (Fn)-binding protein in L iners AB-1 was of interest as it contains a motif (fibronectin-binding protein A) common to pathogenic strains of Staphylococcus aureus, where it mediates adhesion and internalization into the host cells. 16 Although there is no evidence that L iners internalizes into the host cells, 15 protein predictions suggest L iners may adhere to the vaginal epithelium via Fn. Fibronectin is a 454 kDa glycoprotein found in a soluble form in the plasma and in an insoluble form in the extracellular matrix and attached to the surface of host cells. We demonstrate here that L iners AB-1 binds strongly to the human Fn and that this process is protein mediated.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: The overall design of the experiments was to determine the extent of binding of L iners to Fn, to compare it to a well-known binder, S aureus, in order to better understand how the lactobacilli might utilize the glycoprotein for persistence in the vagina.

sec.title: Strains and Growth Conditions
sec.p: The strains used in this study are listed in Table 1. Lactobacillus rhamnosus GR-1, L rhamnosus GG, L reuteri RC-14, and L crispatus American Type Culture Collection 33820 were grown in de Man, Rogosa, and Sharpe (MRS) agar and broth (Difco, Maryland), anerobically at 37°C under static conditions. Lactobacillus iners AB-1 was grown on Columbia blood agar (Difco), then subcultured in 10 mL of MRS broth and grown anerobically at 37°C overnight under static conditions. Growth of L iners AB-1 in MRS broth is shown in Figure 1. Staphylococcus aureus MN8 was grown in brain heart infusion (Difco) agar and broth at 37°C aerobically with agitation.

caption.p: Lactobacillus iners AB-1 grown in 10 mL de Man, Rogosa, and Sharpe (MRS) broth for 7 days. The bars represent standard deviation.
Bacterial Strains Used in This Study

tr.td: Distal urethral isolate; from a healthy woman 17
Vaginal isolate; from a healthy woman 17
Clinical isolate from patient with menstrual toxic shock syndrome (TSS) 20

sec.title: Fibronectin adhesion assay
sec.p: Binding of bacteria to immobilized Fn was measured according to the methods of Munoz-Provencio et al. 21 Briefly, 96-well Polysorp plates (Nunc, Rochester, New York) were coated with 50 µg/mL human Fn (Sigma Chem. Co, St Louis, Missouri) in carbonate/bicarbonate buffer 50 mmol/L pH 9.6 and incubated at 4°C overnight. The wells were washed 3 times with 100 µL phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; pH 7.4), then blocked with 100 µL of PBS + 1% Tween 20 for 1 hour. All strains were grown to late exponential phase (54 hours for L iners AB-1, 5-6 hours for all other strains tested), washed 3 times with PBS, and resuspended in PBS to an optical density that represented 107 colony-forming unit (CFU)/mL as determined previously by the growth curves. Then 100 µL of each strain was added to each well and incubated at 37°C for 2 hours. After incubation, nonadherent cells were removed by 3 washes with 200 µL PBS + 0.05% Tween 20. The adhered cells were stained with 100 µL of 1 mg/mL crystal violet for 45 minutes. After washing, the colorant was released with 100 µL citrate buffer (50 mmol/L, pH 4.0) and the absorbance at 600 nm was measured in a Multiskan Ascent plate reader (Thermo-Scientific, Rockford). Drop dilution plates using 10 µL of the culture and series of 10 times dilutions were performed simultaneously with binding assays to enumerate bacterial numbers upon addition to Fn-coated plates. Experiments were repeated 3 times and in triplicate.

The effect of protease treatment was assayed by incubating cells with 100 µg/mL proteinase K for 1 hour at 37°C followed by 1 hour incubation with 1 mmol/L phenylmethanesulfonylfluoride (PMSF) to inactivate proteinase K. The cells were then transferred to Fn-coated plate. Experiments were repeated twice and in duplicate. Wells without Fn were run as controls in all the experiments and their absorbance values were subtracted from the Fn-coated wells. The PBS alone was included in all experiments to account for any Fn binding by PBS.

sec.title: Bacterial binding to Fn-coated cover slips
sec.p: Binding of bacteria to Fn-coated cover slips was determined by coating glass cover slips overnight with 50 μg/mL of Fn in PBS + 0.05% Tween 20 at 4°C. The slips (VWR 18 mm glass) were washed 3 times with 1 mL PBS and blocked with 1 mL PBS + 1% Tween 20 for 1 hour. The cells were grown to late exponential phase, washed twice with PBS, and diluted to a concentration of 107 CFU/mL with PBS. The numbers were confirmed by drop plating. Then 1 mL of these cultures was added to separate cover slips and incubated for 2 hours at 37°C. Nonadherent cells were removed by 3 washes with PBS + 0.05% Tween 20. The cover slips were then Gram stained and adherent cells were viewed under a Zeiss Axioscop HBO50 light microscope under ×100 objective. Cover slips without Fn were run as controls in all the experiments. Five fields of view were recorded for each cover slip and biological replicates were repeated three times to confirm the results.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed on all data from binding assays using the GraphPad Prism 4 program (GraphPad Software, Inc., La Jolla, California). The data fitted a normal distribution and were therefore appropriate for analysis of variance (ANOVA) testing. Differences between the normally distributed means were compared using a 1-way ANOVA analysis with a Tukeys post hoc test. Differences in binding were considered significant with P values of <.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Lactobacillus iners AB-1 bound to Fn-coated polystyrene plates in significantly greater amounts than all strains tested (Figure 2). The effect of proteinase K, a serine protease, was determined by incubating bacteria with proteinase K followed by the protease inhibitor PMSF before addition of cells to Fn-coated plates. Proteinase K treatment significantly reduced binding of L iners AB-1 to Fn (P < .05; Figure 3).

caption.p: Bacterial binding to immobilized fibronectin as measured by optical density at 600 nm (OD600). All strains were added to fibronectin-coated plates at a concentration of 107 CFU/mL unless indicated and bacterial numbers were confirmed by drop plating. Binding by Lactobacillus iners AB-1 is significantly greater than all strains (P < .05). The bars represent standard deviation.

Effect of proteinase K pretreatment on adhesion to immobilized fibronectin by Lactobacillus iners AB-1. Phenylmethanesulfonylfluoride is a proteinase K inhibitor. Lactobacillus iners AB-1 binding was significantly reduced by proteinase K pretreatment (P < .05). The bars represent standard deviation.

sec.p: Photomicrograph images of the cells adhering to Fn-coated and uncoated cover slips are shown in Figure 3 and bacterial cells counts in Table 2. Adhesion of L iners AB-1 and S aureus MN8 was enhanced by coating slips with Fn. There was no difference in adhesion to Fn of L iners AB-1 compared to S aureus (P > .05). The addition of Fn had no effect on the adhesion of L crispatus (P > .05).

caption.p: Bacterial Adhesion to Fibronectin-Coated Cover Slips Cell Countsa

fn.p: aCounts represent an average of 3 fields of view ± standard deviation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The concentration of Fn in the vagina has been reported from as high as 90 to 140 pg/mL during menses to 3 to 5 pg/mL at the end of the menstrual cycle. 22 As L iners possesses a predicted Fn-binding protein and adhesion is the first step in colonization of a surface, we hypothesized that strong adhesion to Fn could be contributing to its persistence in the human vagina. 15 Lactobacillus iners AB-1 bound significantly greater to human Fn compared to other Lactobacillus strains tested, including vaginal probiotic L rhamnosus GR-1 and L reuteri RC-14, and gut probiotic L rhamnosus GG (Figure 4), none of which are able to persist long term in the vagina. However, since strains L rhamnosus GR-1 and L reuteri RC-14 help restore the vaginal microbiota back to a healthy state, 23,24 they must use different adhesion mechanisms, such as extracellular polysaccharides or metabolic pathways, in the vagina.

caption.p: Bacterial adhesion to fibronectin-coated cover slips. A, Lactobacillus iners + fibronectin. B, Lactobacillus iners no fibronectin. C, Staphylococcus aureus + fibronectin. D, Staphylococcus aureus no fibronectin. E, Lactobacillus crispatus + fibronectin. F, Lactobacillus crispatus no fibronectin.

sec.p: In relation to pregnancy, fetal Fn is found in the amniotic fluid, placental tissue, and the decidua basalis, but its presence in the cervicovaginal secretions between 22 and 37 weeks may be due to disruption of the chorionic–decidual interface secondary to infection. 25 Hypothetically, L iners could bind to Fn and potentially counter pathogenesis thereby extending the duration of the pregnancy. Since L iners has only relatively recently been discovered and detected using molecular methodologies, no studies have looked for its presence during elevated Fn and infection. Investigations of this nature perhaps warrant undertaking.

This is the first report of L iners having such strong adhesion to a mucosal protein. This trend was confirmed by viewing cells bound to Fn-coated cover slips under a light microscope (Figure 4). Interestingly, L iners AB-1 bound equally or stronger to Fn compared to S aureus MN8, a species well studied for its Fn-binding properties. 16 Lactobacillus crispatus, another member of the core vaginal microbiota, lacks Fn-binding properties, indicating that L iners and L crispatus use different adhesion mechanisms to colonize the same environment. This is particularly interesting since L crispatus strains do not appear to persist to the extent of L iners, and their displacement coincides with the onset of BV. 1 When candidate probiotic strain L crispatus CTV-05 did colonize hosts who lacked indigenous L crispatus, a healthy state was maintained. 26 It is not clear how BV organisms induce L crispatus and not L iners displacement, but the avidity of adhesion to Fn of the latter likely plays a role. A recent study using atomic force microscopy highlighted the weaker adhesion of L crispatus and L jensenii and suggested that for Lactobacillus species to displace pathogens, they need to display strong adhesion forces. 27 This is not ubiquitous across Lactobacillus, and Nagy et al 28 found only 9 (16.7%) of the 54 vaginal Lactobacillus isolates that bound Fn at pH 7.2; however, L iners was not included as it had not yet been discovered. They also observed that adhesion to Fn increased when the pH was lowered to 4.0. This may help explain the loss of some Lactobacillus species during BV, where the pH is elevated. It also suggests that L iners is able to persist during incidences of BV in part due to its ability to bind Fn at a more neutral pH as shown in our study.

To determine whether Fn adhesion by L iners was protein mediated, we pretreated cells with the serine protease, proteinase K. This treatment significantly reduced binding to Fn (P < .05), confirming that Fn adherence by L iners AB-1 is protein mediated. A predicted Fn-binding protein (LINAB1_0564) in L iners AB-1 could be contributing to this interaction. This protein has 34% amino acid similarity to Fn-binding protein of S aureus MN8. Furthermore, analysis of the transcriptome of L iners has revealed that this gene is expressed in both healthy patients and those with BV (manuscript submitted), indicating the protein may be used during both conditions to adhere to the vaginal mucosa and colonize the vagina.

In summary, the persistence of L iners in the vagina despite the presence of other lactobacilli and pathogens or antibiotics could be due to its strong adhesion to Fn. If clones of this species do indeed form an environment that allows restitution of a Lactobacillus microbiota that protects against disease, future probiotic strains, such as those used against human immunodeficiency virus 29,30 or the ones devised to compete with Fn-binding Trichomonas 31 could benefit from cloning of the L iners Fn-binding protein.
